articles.headline: Why Facebook’s Blocking of New Political Ads May Fall Short
articles.snippet: There are still many ways that voter misinformation can spread on the social network, even as it moves to cut off new political ads on Oct. 27.
articles.abstract: There are still many ways that voter misinformation can spread on the social network, even as it moves to cut off new political ads on Oct. 27.
articles.lead_paragraph: To limit voter misinformation ahead of November’s election, Facebook said this week that it would block new political ads from appearing on its site in the week before Election Day.
articles.byline: By Davey Alba and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: Job Growth Slackens, Signaling Vulnerability of Recovery
articles.snippet: Unemployment fell to 8.4% in August, but the gain of 1.4 million jobs was the weakest in months. The end of federal aid programs is casting a shadow.
articles.abstract: Unemployment fell to 8.4% in August, but the gain of 1.4 million jobs was the weakest in months. The end of federal aid programs is casting a shadow.
articles.lead_paragraph: Job growth slowed further last month, the latest sign that the economy’s spring momentum has faded — and a warning that the recovery could go into reverse this fall without further government support.

articles.headline: Coronavirus Crisis Shatters India’s Big Dreams
articles.snippet: The country’s ambitions to become a global power, lift its poor and update its military have been set back by a sharp economic plunge, soaring infections and a widening sense of malaise.
articles.abstract: The country’s ambitions to become a global power, lift its poor and update its military have been set back by a sharp economic plunge, soaring infections and a widening sense of malaise.
articles.lead_paragraph: SURAT, India — The hit that India’s dreams have taken from the coronavirus pandemic can be found in the hushed streets of Surat’s industrial zone.

articles.headline: Parents Got More Time Off. Then the Backlash Started.
articles.snippet: Pandemic policies at tech companies have created a rift between parents offered more benefits and resentful workers who don’t have children.
articles.abstract: Pandemic policies at tech companies have created a rift between parents offered more benefits and resentful workers who don’t have children.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — When the coronavirus closed schools and child care centers and turned American parenthood into a multitasking nightmare, many tech companies rushed to help their employees. They used their comfortable profit margins to extend workers new benefits, including extra time off for parents to help them care for their children.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: How Trump Draws on Campaign Funds to Pay Legal Bills
articles.snippet: As he has done with other aspects of the presidency, Donald J. Trump has redefined the practice in ways that have unsettled even some Republicans.
articles.abstract: As he has done with other aspects of the presidency, Donald J. Trump has redefined the practice in ways that have unsettled even some Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump was proudly litigious before his victory in 2016 and has remained so in the White House. But one big factor has changed: He has drawn on campaign donations as a piggy bank for his legal expenses to a degree far greater than any of his predecessors.

articles.headline: Race for Coronavirus Vaccine Pits Spy Against Spy
articles.snippet: The intelligence wars over vaccine research have intensified as China and Russia expand their efforts to steal American work at both research institutes and companies.
articles.abstract: The intelligence wars over vaccine research have intensified as China and Russia expand their efforts to steal American work at both research institutes and companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Chinese intelligence hackers were intent on stealing coronavirus vaccine data, so they looked for what they believed would be an easy target. Instead of simply going after pharmaceutical companies, they conducted digital reconnaissance on the University of North Carolina and other schools doing cutting-edge research.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes and Michael Venutolo-Mantovani

articles.headline: The Battle Over Biscuits and Gravy at the 11-Worth Cafe
articles.snippet: In “levelheaded” Omaha, a protester was killed and, in the aftermath, people demanding an end to racial injustice set their sights on police budgets — and a diner with Robert E. Lee on the menu.
articles.abstract: In “levelheaded” Omaha, a protester was killed and, in the aftermath, people demanding an end to racial injustice set their sights on police budgets — and a diner with Robert E. Lee on the menu.
articles.lead_paragraph: Omaha’s 11-Worth Cafe served standard American breakfast fare of omelets, hash browns, bacon and eggs and, without much notice until June, a dish called the Robert E. Lee: two sausage patties smooshed between biscuits and smothered in gravy.

articles.headline: A New Front in America’s Pandemic: College Towns
articles.snippet: The coronavirus is spiking around campuses from Texas to Iowa to North Carolina as students return.
articles.abstract: The coronavirus is spiking around campuses from Texas to Iowa to North Carolina as students return.
articles.lead_paragraph: IOWA CITY, Iowa — Last month, facing a budget shortfall of at least $75 million because of the pandemic, the University of Iowa welcomed thousands of students back to its campus — and into the surrounding community.
articles.byline: By Sarah Watson, Shawn Hubler, Danielle Ivory and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: In Final Stretch, Biden Defends Lead Against Trump’s Onslaught
articles.snippet: The president is attempting to overtake his Democratic challenger with a strategy of racial polarization in heavily white Midwestern states, even as Democrats make inroads in the Republican-leaning South and West.
articles.abstract: The president is attempting to overtake his Democratic challenger with a strategy of racial polarization in heavily white Midwestern states, even as Democrats make inroads in the Republican-leaning South and West.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns, Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: A Weapon for Extortion Long Ignored in Alabama Prisons: Cellphones
articles.snippet: Families say they have been threatened by call and text into sending thousands of dollars to protect loved ones on the inside. Some suffered anyway.
articles.abstract: Families say they have been threatened by call and text into sending thousands of dollars to protect loved ones on the inside. Some suffered anyway.
articles.lead_paragraph: Families say they have been threatened by call and text into sending thousands of dollars to protect loved ones on the inside. Some suffered anyway.
articles.byline: By Serge F. Kovaleski and Dan Barry

articles.headline: Joe Biden’s China Journey
articles.snippet: As a United States senator, he spoke of transforming China through trade. As a presidential candidate two decades later, he denounces it as a “dictatorship.”
articles.abstract: As a United States senator, he spoke of transforming China through trade. As a presidential candidate two decades later, he denounces it as a “dictatorship.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a steamy August day along the Chinese coast, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. stepped off a minibus at a seaside compound for a series of unusual meetings with China’s Communist Party leaders.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong, Michael Crowley and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: For Aging Belarus Rockers, a Late Shot at Stardom
articles.snippet: Forced underground in the 1990s to a life of cover gigs and guitar lessons, they are re-emerging amid the country’s political awakening.
articles.abstract: Forced underground in the 1990s to a life of cover gigs and guitar lessons, they are re-emerging amid the country’s political awakening.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINSK, Belarus — Pit Pawlaw, guitar in hand, bobbed before the line of riot police guarding the presidential palace, belting out the chorus of his band’s biggest hit even as a siren blared. The protesters joined in behind him: “Hey, la-la-la-lai, don’t wait, don’t wait.”

articles.headline: In Year of Voting by Mail, a Scramble to Beef Up In-Person Voting, Too
articles.snippet: Communities are running short on time to hire poll workers and reconfigure in-person voting to make it safe during a pandemic.
articles.abstract: Communities are running short on time to hire poll workers and reconfigure in-person voting to make it safe during a pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Unnerved by the difficulties of voting amid a pandemic and faced with both the political static injected by President Trump and the limits on expanding voting by mail, state and local authorities across the country are racing to rethink and reinforce the polling sites where tens of millions of people are still expected to cast their ballots.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti and Michael Wines

articles.headline: Xi’s Post-Virus Economic Strategy for China Looks Inward
articles.snippet: The Chinese leader’s latest approach calls for a more robust domestic economy to insulate growth from tensions with the United States.
articles.abstract: The Chinese leader’s latest approach calls for a more robust domestic economy to insulate growth from tensions with the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: He inspected fields of corn amid jitters about food supplies. He visited steel works trying to overcome a slump in profits. He toured an innovation center at a time when President Trump has raised barriers against China’s technological takeoff.

articles.headline: Looking to Buy a Used Car in the Pandemic? So Is Everyone Else
articles.snippet: Eager to avoid public transit and Uber, and to save money, buyers are emptying dealerships.
articles.abstract: Eager to avoid public transit and Uber, and to save money, buyers are emptying dealerships.
articles.lead_paragraph: Used cars are usually overlooked in the fanfare accorded to cutting-edge electric cars and gussied-up pickup trucks. Now they are suddenly the industry’s hottest commodity.

articles.headline: With Washington Deadlocked on Aid, States Face Dire Fiscal Crises
articles.snippet: Local officials are slashing funding for everything from education and health care to orchestra subsidies.
articles.abstract: Local officials are slashing funding for everything from education and health care to orchestra subsidies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alaska chopped resources for public broadcasting. New York City gutted a nascent composting program that could have kept tons of food waste out of landfills. New Jersey postponed property-tax relief payments.
